Posts.Content: Aug 17, 2014 08:35PM pcrandall wrote:      I am 66, nearly 67, and still working with good insurance.  However, retirement is in my near future; I will then be insured by Medicare.  Can anyone tell me her experience with Medicare with such things as co-pay, deductible, etc.?  I now take Xeloda which, I believe, is covered by part B; however, that could change and probably will.  What happens when your meds are covered by your part D plan, you change plans, and your meds are not part of your existing part D?  Having to even think about insurance coverage tires me out, and I am fatigued enough already.      Thanks.

Posts.Content: Sep 2, 2013 03:37PM pcrandall wrote:      Hi, Sissy.      I have been the A/A combination since March of 2012.  I was my doctor's first patient to go this route, and it has been a miracle for me.  I have experienced most of the symptoms listed for Afinitor usage, but they have all been mild and most have passed.  Fatigue is the only symptom still present.  Naps are my best friends on weekends.      My last scan was in April of 2013, and it showed no evidence of disease.  The process takes time, so be patient.  In the meantime, take care of yourself.      My gift to myself has been to start working only part time this year.  I am a teacher and have worked full time since my diagnosis in late 2009 (except for a quarter and summer during the most rigorous time of treatment); but when the new year begins tomorrow, I will be teaching four classes a day rather than six.      I know all will go well for you.  Take care.  We can be thankful there are multiple treatment options available today.
Posts.Title: New to Afinitor/Aromasin - Recommendations? Results? sissy2010 pcrandall

Posts.Content: Sep 24, 2014 11:28AM pcrandall wrote:      Trick-or-Treat for UNICEF boxes are still available.  At least they were last year when I ordered some on-line.  My students do a research paper every October about UNICEF and collect money.  Most of the kids just bring in money from home or donate the change left from their cafeteria purchases.  Some, however, take the boxes home and trick-or-treat for UNICEF on Halloween night.  Last year we collected $192.      It is interesting that most of the kids do not know about UNICEF before we do this paper.  Cartoon Network used to be a UNICEF sponsor and advertised for the cause; I don't think that is the case any more.
Posts.Title: OT Unicef boxes at Halloween Rosevalley Rosevalley

Posts.Content: Aug 27, 2014 10:35AM pcrandall wrote:      I was diagnosed with liver mets in December, 2011.  I am still doing well.  I have been on Afinitor/Aromasin which worked very well, Faslodex which didn't, and now Xeloda which seems to be doing the job.  I have a few aches and pains but nothing intolerable.  I am at age 66 still teaching part time and loving it; I take my grandkids on "grandma's fieldtrips" which included trips this summer to the Statue of Liberty/ Ellis Island, the Grand Canyon, the Long Beach Aquarium, and Sea World to swim with the dolphins.  I exercise daily, work in my garden, and spend quality time with my hubby.  My biggest concession to C has been to get more sleep; I am usually in bed by 8:30 P.M.  I get up between 5:30 A.M. and 6:00 A.M.      It is difficult sometimes to stay focused on the present and enjoying every day.  When I think about the things I might not be here to see in my family's future, I tell myself, "STOP!  ENJOY THIS MOMENT.  MAKE MEMORIES WITH YOUR KIDS AND GRANDKIDS."  Self talk helps bring me back to what I have today.      Enough of my thoughts.  Take care all.
Posts.Title: Anyone with Liver Mets ? Help Mary-Lou Mary-Lou
